description.narrative: AECF-Agribusiness Window for Tanzania is a challenge fund that aims to co-finance and stimulate, innovative and catalytic private agri-business investments in Tanzania. It is implemented by AGRA (Alliance for Green Revloution in Africa).

Tilläggsbeslutet gäller ett tillskott till AECF för att finansiera en tredje runda av Tanzania Agri-business Window (TZAW) där företag kan söka stöd för affärsmodeller inom jordbrukssektorn som gynnar människor som lever i fattigdom. Ett antal vinnande företag väljs ut bland annat baserat på hur väl och hur många fattiga människor kan dra nytta av företagets affärsmodell, som producenter, konsumenter, leverantörer mm.
Tidigare stöd har gått till runda två av TZAW och Renewable Energy and Climate Change Adaptation Technologies (REACT-TZ). Det är ännu för tidigt att rapportera resultat från dessa två utlysningar, men rapportering från första rundan (ej finansierad av Sida-stöd) visar resultat i linje med uppsatta målsättningar och visar att modellen fungerar väl.
Det bedöms finnas ett ansenligt antal lovande företag inom jordbrukssektorn i Tanzania som skulle kunna kvalificera för AECF-stöd. Utifrån goda förutsättningar och baserat på erfarenheter av redan pågående verksamhet genom AECF i Tanzania bedöms ett stöd till en tredje runda av TZAW vara relevant. Den tredje rundan kommer att innebära en väsentlig ökning av det förväntade antalet människor som ska öka sina inkomster som en följd av projekten.

description.narrative: In general, the reported results indicate that the progress towards the overall plan based on AECF core mandate is on track with minor deviation. The deviation was mainly caused by lack of flow of funds (investees interrupted drawdown) and policy and business environment related to agriculture in general. The interrupted investees’ drawdown was because the 2019 annual plan and budgets for both windows were not approved following the whistleblower alert with allegations of AECF's management weaknesses, which prompted Sida to commission an investigative special audit. As a result of Audit, immediate actions were taken and the medium to long-term action plan was agreed and are being implemented. The spending suspension was then lifted following the budget approvals in the last quarter of 2019 followed by a formal approval communication in January 2020. The projects under TZAW have benefited a total of 280,912 households, surpassing the 2020 target of 198,766 households. Round 2 (R2) with a total of 202,571 direct beneficiaries, of which total of 48,617 beneficiaries is directly attributed to Sida and the reminder of 153,954 direct beneficiaries is attributable to DFID, while R3 beneficiaries are estimated at 21,534 direct beneficiaries, of which 10,767 are directly attributable to Sida funding while 10,767 are attributable to DFID finding. These projects have created 1,725 (of which 827 are women) jobs, paid out US$8,585,493 in total wages and created US $49,320,643 in total development impact. These investments have leveraged a total of US$74 million in matching funds. R4 has registered a total of 47,555 direct beneficiaries which are 100% attributable to DFID as the only funding agency supporting that window/round. Copying of the business model (Replication) and Crowding-in: Since the challenge fund increases opportunities and choices for the poor to be able to participate in economic activities and there by create and own wealth (resources), the 2019 reports documented best practices from TZAW grantees projects, which has started to attract the interest of copying the business models from other non-TZAW financed businesses. The cooperation partner reported an example from an innovation by Kilombero Plantations, System Rice Intensification (SRI), being copied by surrounding smallholder farmers and other companies in other regions. Crowding in by other goods and support service businesses is also reported, ranging from small scale vendors such as women food restaurants selling to paid workers and suppliers of TZAW projects to big businesses such as Banking and inputs suppliers opening the branches or showing interest in funding groups of farmers who are contracted by TZAW-funded projects. The TZAW expects that replication of successful and innovative models will allow for broad change across the Tanzanian agribusiness markets
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
